loans.use: To purchase more ducks to lay eggs

loans.name: Munira

texts.ru:
Munira Shukurilloevna I. has been trading at the market for 16 years. She is divorced and lives with her parents. She dreams of purchasing her own home. The income she receives from her business is not sufficient in order to get a loan, so she plans to purchase a piece of land and begin building a house. During the past two years she has been part of Kiva and has been an exemplary client. Because of the cold weather, she plans to widen the assortment of goods by purchasing warm jeans.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Иброхимова Мунира Шукуриллоевна в течение 16 лет торгует на рынке. Разведена. Живет с родителями. Мечтает обзавестись собственным жильем. Доход получаемый от бизнеса не достаточен для сформирования ипотечного капитала, поэтому она собирается выкупить земельный участок и постепенно возводить дом. В течение последних 2 лет кредитуется в фонде и является образцовой клиенткой. В связи с наступлением холодов она намерена расширить свой ассортимент посредством приобретения утепленных джинсовых брюк.

loans.use: Purchase of warm jeans

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
Maria Esther is 53 years old and lives in the area called Campina D. Moche in Trujillo. She prepares and sells meals on Saturdays and Sundays in a restaurant called El Zorro. The weekends are key for a good business here, as the town is a main tourist destination. Local people also know Campina D. Moche for its good food, so many families come for lunch on the weekends. She specializes in local dishes such as guinea pig, serrano ham, and a typical potato dish. Maria Esther is a member of the group Mientras Tanto, Siempre Adelante (always forward) from whom she received her first loan to buy rice, oil and other necessities. With this loan, which she will repay in 4 months, she will make necessary repairs to the restaurant so it's more comfortable for her customers.

La señora Maria Esther tiene 53 años D. edad y vive en el Sector Campiña D. Moche del Distrito D. Moche D. la Provincia D. Trujillo del Departamento D. La Libertad. Ella venD. comida los sábados y domingos en el restaurante “El Zorro” ya que estos días son claves para un buen negocio porque la Campiña D. Moche es un lugar turístico cercano a las Huacas del Sol y La Luna, esta zona es visitada por los turistas generalmente los fines D. semana además la gente sabe que en la Campiña D. Moche se come muy bien y hay muchas familias que van a pasear y comer a esa zona los fines D. semana. Se ha especializado en la preparación D. cuyes, jamón serrano y papa a la huancaina (comidas propias D. la zona). La señora María Esther es socia del Grupo Mientras Tanto “Siempre Adelante” en este grupo obtuvo su primer préstamo D. S/.300.00 con este dinero compró un saco D. arroz, un bidón D. aceite y menestras. Con este préstamo D. S/.500.00 soles, que cancelará en cuatro meses, lo empleará para arreglar su restaurante y hacerlo más acogedor.

loans.use: TO MAKE NECESSARY REPAIRS TO HER RESTAURANT SO IT'S MORE COMFORTABLE FOR THE CUSTOMERS.

loans.name: Rosa Amelia

texts.es:
Mrs. Rosa Amelia belongs to the “Bold Women” Comunal Bank, she lives in the San Martin region, province and district of Moyabamba. She displays her business in a kiosk located in the “Tioyacy” parking lot, where she services the interior towns of the province, because of this her clientele is pretty fluid and her sales are secured by her good deals and her good seasonings and cleanliness. She began selling grilled meats, but like a good businesswoman she saw that the sales of food from a menu were more profitable, because of this she decided to change her business partnering herself with a friend, and together they are furthering their families. With the loan of 2,000 soles, that which she will pay in one installment in 6 months, she will finish paying for the cooking gas that she bought, furthermore it will serve her to acquire the ingredients for the preparation of the food like rice, sugar, vegetables at wholesale, beef, chicken, pork and fish, also in kilograms, that will allow her to prepare various food for her clients. Rosa Amelia is a young woman of 38 years, peaceful, enthusiastic and persevering who desires a better future for her children and has dreams of constructing her own house and insuring a roof over their heads and to give them a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa Amelia pertenece al banco comunal ” Mujeres Audaces”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia y distrito de Moyabamba. Desarrolla su negocio en un kiosco ubicado en el paradero de autos “Tioyacu”, el cual realiza servicio a los pueblos del interior de la provincia, por lo que la clientela es bastante fluida y sus ventas están aseguradas dado su buen trato y su buena sazón y limpieza. Se inició vendiendo parrillas de carne de pollo, pero como buena negociante vio que era más rentable la venta de comida tipo menú, por lo que decidió cambiar de negocio asociándose con una amiga, juntas están sacando adelante a sus familias. Con el préstamo de S/ 2,000.00, el cual pagará en un plazo de 6 meses, terminará de pagar la cocina a gas que compró, además le servirá para adquirir los insumos para la preparación de los alimentos como arroz, azúcar, menestras al por mayor, verduras en todas sus variedades por kilogramos, carnes de res, pollo, cerdo y pescado, también en kilogramos, que le permitirá preparar comida variada a sus clientes. Rosa Amelia es una mujer joven de 38 años, tranquila, entusiasta y perseverante que desea un futuro mejor para sus hijos por lo que sueña con construir su propia casa y asegurarles un techo y darles una buena educación.

loans.use: Money for cooking and the purchase of ingredients for cooking.

loans.name: Askerkhan

texts.en: Askerkhan Z. lives in the Devechi village of Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. He is 58 years old, married and has four children. He is engaged in cattle breeding. He has ten years' experience at this business. He needs a loan in the amount of $400 for developing his business.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 54-year-old Catherine M.. She is married, and has three children. Between 29 and 39 people depend on her for support. In 2004, Catherine established her cereals business. Catherine requires a loan in order to purchase additional stock of maize, rice and beans in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of leasing and leaseback microfinance, as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of rice, maize and beans in bulk.

loans.name: New Life 2020-2 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Betty C.. She is currently in the business of baking bread and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Betty is 29 years old and is married; her husband is a teacher. She has 2 children, ages 6 and 12 and her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately 400 Sudanese pounds (about US$ 195) in profit and with the extra money from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

Betty is joined in her small group by Hellen J., Mary B., Betty K., and Poni J.. Hellen J. has a business brewing alcohol and wants to expand the business. Mary B. is currently operating a business selling bread and wants a loan to expand her business. Betty K. operates a business selling beer and wants to expand the business. Poni J. is currently in the business of selling at a hotel and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: expand their business

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov is an entrepreneur from Zaporoshye, which is located in the south-central region of Ukraine. She is divorced and her children are all grownups. She has a small business where she sells children’s toys, board games, and sporting goods at one of the large outdoor markets in Zaporoshye. Lubov is fortunate to have an excellent location for her sales kiosk because the combination of such a good location and an attractive array of items for sale attracts many prospective customers. In a typical month Lubov generates approximately $300 of profit from her business. The income she generates from her business is not much but is sufficient to enable her to pay for her basic needs.

Lubov is requesting a loan in the amount of 3,500 Ukrainian Griven ($750) to purchase new items for the summer season and to add to her available working capital. She would like to purchase a supply of inflatable toys and sporting goods which are sure to sell well during the warmer time of year.

loans.use: To capitalize on the summer season by purchasing additional inventory (e.g., inflatable toys and sporting goods) in anticipation of warmer weather and to increase the business' available capital

loans.name: Chek

texts.en: Chek S. is 57 years old and sells fruit in the Kampong Cham province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$5 every day. Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions have lead to a poor growing season. She is asking for a loan of US$800 to make two investments. She would like to invest US$500 in her sister’s rice business, and also put US$300 into her own fruit business, increasing her stock of fruit to sell. She sees these investments as opportunities that will be able to increase her daily income.

loans.use: Increasing fruit stock; Investing in sister's rice business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Rehema M.. She has no children. Rehema owns a shop which sells DVD movies. She works six days a week and ten hours a day, and she is assisted by one employee. Rehema is seeking a loan in order to purchase additional DVD movies for her shop. In the future, Rehema plans to to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania, using a sale and leaseback microfinance model as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Because customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, they are deemed not creditworthy by financial institutions, leading low incomes and inadequate access to basic needs and services. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women: when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the client, extends a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment.

loans.use: To purchase additional DVD movies for a shop.

loans.name: Nidia Marilu

texts.es:
Nidia is a member of the Rikchary Community Bank. Rikchary means "to wake up" in Quecha.

Nidia is 30 years old and married with 2 children. With her husband, she has two businesses, one is a tavern called "Ucupis," which means "with in" in Quecha. The tavern is open all night until the early morning, because of which she employes people to work in her business. Also, Nidia has a liquor store which is located on the main street. The liquor store is open at night until the early morning as well, depending on the demand for her products. She also sells beer at various events.

Nidia also has a business in which she is the sole owner, a mail-order cosmetic product and clothing business in the city of Lima.

Nidia needs a 2,000 soles loan to purchase children's and women's clothing. Nidia dreams of having her own house, expanding her businesses, and offering the best to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

Nidia es socia del Banco Comunal Rikchary que significa Despierta en quechua.

Nidia es casada, tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Nidia junto a su esposo tiene dos negocios que es administrado por ambos, tienen una taberna llamado Ucupis que significa adentro en quechua, la atención es por las noches hasta la madrugada, para lo cual cuenta con la ayuda de personal. Además tienen una licorería que se ubica en una avenida principal, el horario de atención es por las noches hasta la madrugada dependiendo de la demanda de sus productos y también reparte cerveza por mayor a diferentes eventos de acuerdo a los pedidos.

Nidia además tiene un negocio que ella sola administra que es la venta de cosméticos por catálogos y ropa que lo adquiere en la ciudad de Lima.

Nidia necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa de niños y damas. Los sueños de Nidia son tener casa propia, ampliar sus negocios, que sus ventas sigan creciendo y brindarles los mejor a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase children's and women's clothing.

loans.name: Fatma's Tawakal Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 30 years old. She is a widow with 4 children aged 12, 8, 5, and 3 years old. She's owned a small food store since 2005. Every day, she works at her business.

Fatma is now looking for a loan to buy more food items to increase her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with banana sales, juice and charcoal sales, shop ownership and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her current stock

loans.name: Ni Komang Suarmi

texts.id: Sudah hampir 10 tahun Komang Suarmi menekuni usahanya mengelola warung di rumahnya sendiri. Dengan mulai berjualan dari jam 07.00 pagi hingga jam 09.00 malam dengan menjual berbagai kebutuhan pokok serta makanan dan minuman. Modal awal yang dipakai Komang untuk memulai usahanya ini sekitar Rp.1000.000,- dan memang dirasakan sangat kurang karena barang-barang dagangan yang dijual hanya berkisar itu-itu saja. Untuk meningkatkan hasil dari usahanya ini sehingga paling tidak mampu membantu suami yang hanya sebagai petani akhirnya Komang bertekad untuk menambah modal usahanya dengan meminjam ke DINARI melalui program Tempek. Pinjaman dengan jangka waktu 12 bulan dan pembayaran cicilan setiap bulan ini akan dipakai untuk menambah omset barang dagangan yang akan dikembangkannya kearah penjualan barang-barang pokok kebutuhan dapur. Para pelanggan pun bertambah karena semakin lengkapnya barang dagangan di warung Komang Suarmi. Keuntungan bersih yang diperoleh setiap bulannya hampir Rp.300.000,- dan hal ini sangat membantu Komang dan suaminya dalam memenuhi kebutuhan sehari-hari serta menyekolahkan anaknya di bangku SD disamping juga memenuhi kebutuhan anak keduanya yang masih bayi. Kerjasama dengan DINARI meskipun baru pertama kali tetapi dirasakan sangat membantu meningkatkan taraf kehidupan dari Komang Suarmi.
texts.en:
It has almost been 10 years since Komang Suarmi running her small grocery store in her house. She sells various goods, food and beverages, and opens the store at 7.00 am until 9.00 pm. The initial capital outlaid for the business was Rp 1,000,000. Komang Suarmi realizes that there should be more amounts deployed, so that goods sold can be more in number and varieties, but it was all they had. To improve her grocery store that will help her husband who is only a farmer in fulfilling their daily needs, Komang propose to earn loan from DINARI through Tempek Program. Komang will use the 12 months loan with monthly installment to increase the number and the variety of goods sold, especially the variety of seasonings and kitchen materials. Komang is sure that the more variety her grocery store provides, the more customer will shop, and the more she will earn. Komang is able to earn Rp 300,000 a month from the store. The income is really usefull, especially to help her husband to fulfill their family daily needs and to fund their child’s tuition fee, as well as to raise their toddler. The first cooperation with DINARI will be very helpful to Komang Suarmi and her family.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana Dyah Kuntari, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the number and varieties of goods sold

loans.name: Akuwa

texts.en: Mrs. A. is the leader of a group called UNION. She is receiving the loan on behalf of the whole group. The group is composed of three dynamic women, who are Batchassi Pierrette, A. Akouwa and Passai Celestine. Like A., the other members of the group also specialize in charcoal businesses. The entire group is requesting a loan of 900 dollars, to share the total amount equally among the three members. Because the market is flourishing and they have been selling charcoal for years, they are sure that they could sell and make some profit. They will use half of the profit of each month for their families' basic needs (food, particularly) and the other half to pay back the loan. They estimate to pay back the total amount within 18 months. Thank you for supporting their small businesses.

loans.use: To buy charcoal from a rural area and sell it in town

loans.name: Favour

texts.en: Favour G. is single. She sells drinks and pepper soup in her shop. Since the festive season is approaching, she hopes to increase her business. She is requesting this loan to purchase more drinks to sell to her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Fatana Group

texts.en:
Nabela is the group leader of the Fatana group. There are three members in this group. Each of them would like to receive a loan for her own business. Zabida and Zakara want to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Nabela wants to take a loan for her bead business. They all want to see progress in their businesses and to earn more money to support their families better in future.

They want to say that they appreciate these loans people in Afghanistan can use to further their businesses and make larger businesses. They want to thank those involved in the Kiva process to support poor people.

loans.use: to help their businesses progress

loans.name: Teu

texts.en:
Mr. Teu P. is a villager in Thmey village in Kampong Speu province. He is a blacksmith. 

In his business, he faces an obstacle because his motor does not work. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to repair his motor. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's living conditions with this loan. 

His wife, Mrs. Men Pao, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Mr. Teu P. is 38 years old and the father of three children who are attending the local school. His wife is with him in the picture.

loans.use: To repair his motor.

loans.name: Estelvina Irene

texts.es: La Sra. Estelvina vende ropa, zapatos y productos de cosméticos desde hace seis años, que con propios esfuerzos y ahorros y ayuda de su esposo comenzó la venta de ropa, tiene 49 años de edad, y reside en anexo villa libertad del centro de salud 1 c al este 13 andenes al sur, con tres hijos de 8,10 y 22 años de edad, el mayor trabaja y los dos estudian la primaria en el colegio del barrio, su esposo trabaja de maestro de obra, en los diferentes construcciones del país, trabajo que es pesado pero se gana regular y por su familia todo lo puede, doña Estelvina hace prestamos en Afodenic desde hace ocho ciclos que ha sido de beneficios para las mejoras a su negocio, con esta solicitud va invertir en comprar ropa y zapatos para aumentar su inventario y vender mas y poder cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes. a futuro es poder hacer mas grande su negocio y seguir ayudando a sus hijas a que se preparen con sus estudio.
texts.en:
Estelvina has been selling clothes, shoes and cosmetics for six years. She started selling clothes through her own efforts, savings and the help of her husband. She is 49 years old, and lives in Villa Libertad with three children ages 8, 10, and 22. The oldest works, and the other two are studying primary at the neighborhood’s school. Her husband works as a master builder at different construction projects in the country, work that is difficult but provides steady income and he does all he can for his family. Estelvina has taken loans through Afodenic for eight cycles, and they have been of great benefit to her business. With this request, she will invest in the purchase of more clothes and shoes to increase her inventory, sell more, and meet the demand of her customers. In the future, she would like to expand her business and continue helping her daughters to prepare themselves with their educations.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Fausto Ramiro

texts.es: El Señor Fausto Ramiro R. L. tiene 31 años de edad, su estado civil es casado. Don Fausto tiene 1 hijo. La actividad económica de Don Fausto es la compra y venta de ropa. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio y cuenta con el poyo de su esposa, esta actividad se desarrolla por la necesidad de proveer ingresos para la familia. Por lo que los propósitos de Don Fausto son de mantener a sus clientes es por eso que tiene que invertir en una variedad de productos. El financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de ropa, cosméticos y otros artículos. Los sueños de Don Fausto son de establecer una  pequeña tienda para ofertar sus productos. La cantidad que solicita es de C$ 14.500 córdobas.
texts.en:
Mr. Fausto Ramiro R. L. is 31 years old, married, and has 1 child. Fausto earns a living buying and selling clothing. Over 5 years ago he began working in this business, and he counts with the support of his wife. They carry out this work due to their necessity to provide an income for their family. Fausto intends to maintain his client base and because of this he has to invest in a variety of products. The loan will be used as work capital to purchase clothing, cosmetics, and other articles. Fausto dreams of establishing a small shop where he can offer his products. The amount that he is requesting is 14,500 NIO.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital to purchase clothing, cosmetics, and other articles.

loans.name: Villa Antacocha Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Villa Antacocha pertenece al Proyecto Wari, las socias son D. la comunidad D. Putica que se ubica a 30 minutos D. Cangallo, en el departamento D. ayacucho, las principales actividades D. la comunidad son la agricultura y en menor cantidad la crianza D. animales.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. animales, carne, abarrotes en general y la agricultura.

Como es el caso D. maura que es casada, tiene 2 hijos, Maura venD. golosinas, gaseosas actividad que realiza en su casa, desD. que es socia aprendió mucho a través D. las capacitaciones que recibe, su préstamo lo invertirá en la compra D. mas mercadería para surtir su negocio. Maura sueña con ampliar su negocio y tener un negocio mas granD..

Por otro lado Norma es casada, tiene 2 hijos, Norma compra y venD. cereales, tubérculos, algunos D. los cuales los produce ella en sus tierras y también compra D. los demás productores, su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. mas productos que ofrecerá a mas clientes, Norma sueña con tener un puesto estable donD. venda sus productos y ahorrar para la educación D. sus hijos.
Mientras que Juana es casada, tiene 2 hijos, Juana tiene una pequeña tienda D. abarrotes en su casa, negocio que fue creciendo D. poco, su préstamo invertirá en la compra D. mas productos y surtir mas, Juana sueña con aumentar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 100 soles, 500 soles, 600soles, haciendo un total D. 7,000 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra arroz, azúcar, animales menores, Trigo, cebada.
texts.en:
The "Banco Comunal Villa Antacocha" belongs to the Wari Project, the members are from the community of Putica which is located 30 minutes from Cangallo, in the department of Ayacucho. The main activities of the community are agriculture and some breeding.

The members have different businesses such as sale of animals, meat, groceries and farming. On the other hand, Norma is married with 2 children. She buys and sells cereals, tubers, some of them grown on her own land, and she also buys from other farmers. Her loan will be invested in buying more products to offer to more clients. Norma dreams of having a stable stand where to sell her products and of saving money for the education of her children.

Juana is married with 2 children, she has a small grocery store at home, business that has grown little by little. Her loan will be invested in buying more and varied products. Juana dreams of increasing her business and of giving a good education to her children.

The members need different amounts for the loans such as 100 soles, 500 soles, 600 soles, making a total of 7,000 soles for the "Banco Comunal.

Their loans will be invested in buying rice, sugar, small animals, wheat, and barley.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, small animals, wheat, and barley.

loans.name: Magaly Isabel

texts.es:
La señora Magaly Isabel G. C. tiene 28 años, vive en la Urb. El Cortijo del distrito de Trujillo,  provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió hasta 4to de primaria, abandono los estudios debido a que vino a vivir a Trujillo y no quiso estudiar, tiene 02 pequeños hijos que dependen enteramente de ella.
Magaly se dedica a la venta de pollos, inició su negocio hace 3 meses comprando 15 pollos para criar que luego vendió y le ha sido muy rentable. Su negocio lo desarrolla en su propio domicilio. 
Ella es socia nueva  Banco Comunal “Nuevo Perú”.  Con este crédito de 300 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la  compra de pollos y alimento balanceado.
Magaly sueña con tener una bodega en su domicilio.
texts.en:
Magaly Isabel G. C. is 28 years old and lives in El Cortijo in the Trujillo district of Trujillo Province, in the La Libertad region of Peru.
She went as far as 4th grade, quitting school once she moved to Trujillo and no longer wanted to study. She has two young children who completely depend on her.
Magaly sells chickens from her home. She started her business 3 months ago by purchasing and raising 15 chickens, which she later sold. This was very profitable for her.
She is a new member of the “Nuevo Perú” Communal Bank. With this loan of 300 soles, to be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase chickens and chicken feed.
Magaly dreams of setting up a grocery store in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chickens and chicken feed

loans.name: Lourng

texts.en: Lourng S., 42, is married and lives with her four children in Kampong Cham province. She sells vegetables and fruit for US$7 each day, while her husband is a wedding chef and makes US$3 each day. Lourng S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to expand her business. In order to increase her profits and possibly raise her standard of living, she would like to reinvest in her vegetables store with the loan given to her through CREDIT.

loans.use: To reinvest in her vegetables store.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. is thirty-nine years old. She is widowed and has given birth to three children, two sons and one daughter. She says they are in junior high and primary schools. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. It is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region.

Janet is a petty trader. She trades in maize. She procures bags of maize from farmers in the nearby communities and sells in the local market to retailers. Janet also treks to other towns to sell. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk. Janet is hopeful to expand her business and give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Wédayamana 8 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Wédayamana 8  est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Sirakélé de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles excellent uniquement   dans la culture de l’arachide.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe   Wédayamana 8 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés  les quatre prêts précédents, elles sont à leur cinquième  prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter,  une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, exclusivement  au grand marché de Koutiala ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Wédayamana 8 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 70 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Wédayamana 8 is a group of married women in the Sirakélé neighborhood, in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso Region, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large extended traditional families with their children, husbands, in-laws, etc. They average 28 years of age, and have at least 4 children. Their only business consists in growing peanuts. Eager to make their farming activities profitable, they decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, five years ago. After having repaid the previous four loans without problems, they are now seeking their fifth farming loan. The loan will be used to buy, exclusively at the grand market in Koutiala, peanut seeds, small material, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, crops are stocked for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Koutiala and in the surrounding villages, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities. After selling their production, the members of the Wédayamana 8 group count on turning a profit of XOF 70000 (ca US$ 150), to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seed, small material, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Joylen

texts.en:
Joylen A. is 29 years old and the mother of one child. She helps her husband, Marlon A., manage their small farm. As of now, they are tilling only one hectare. This provides them the food on their table as well as the resources to buy the things they need in their home. 

Thinking of how she could help her husband sustain their livelihood, she applied for a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will be buying two sacks of fertilizer and other farming necessities. She hopes that her loan will help a lot to increase her income.

CEVI is reaching out to people to start and have their own business. They provide loans to support small entrepreneurs as well as insurance coverage to all its members

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and other farming needs

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en: Felipa D. S. is from the village of Casinglot, Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 26 years old, married, and has an infant child. Felipa owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily selling specialty food products like longganisa (Filipino-style sausages), and other sausages in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Felipa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Ibijoke

texts.en: IbijO. sells drinks and wine. She has been in this business for the past 10 years and she lives in Lagos. IbijO. is 45 years old and she has 5 children. IbijO. is a single parent and she is trying to lift her family above poverty. She is requesting a loan of N50,00 to purchase more drinks and wine to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and wine to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is thirty – six years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two sons and two daughters who are all still in school. She works very hard to support her husband who is a trader to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Oda in the Eastern region of Ghana. Agnes is a trader. She trades in second hand textiles – clothes for unisex, bed sheets, etc. She hawks and treks to sell in other communities. Agnes procures bales of second hand textiles from Accra. She has been in business for over twelve years now and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy second hand textiles

loans.name: Soneui Group

texts.en:
Soneui wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a general store. Nazia wants to take out a loan for a quilt making business. Marghli wants to take out a loan for a tailoring business. Ma Parwar wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a shop selling vegetables. Mallahli wants to take out a loan for a shop selling dry fruits.

Soneui is the leader of the Soneui Group. There are five members in this group. Each of them has requested a loan to expand their business. They have requested a group loan 70000 afghani. They are very thankful to Kiva lenders who provide support around the world.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Filomena

texts.es:
Filomena es socia del Banco Comunal Obreras.
Filomena es viuda, tiene 64 años y 7 hijos, Filomena se dedica a la agricultura en la comunidad D. Matara, en donD. siembra quinua, cebada, papa, productos que venD. en el mercado Mariscal Cáceres en donD. tiene un puesto, también compra D. otros productores.
Filomena necesita un préstamo D. 1600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. haba, trigo y quinua.
Los sueños D. Filomena es comprar un carro para el transporte D. pasajeros.
texts.en:
Filomena is a member of the Obreras Communal Bank. She is a 64-year-old widow and has 7 children. She is a farmer in Matara where she cultivates quinoa, barley, and potatoes which she sells at the Mariscal Caceres market where she has a stall; she also purchases other products. Filomena is asking for a 1600 soles loan which will be used to buy beans, wheat and quinoa. Her dream is to buy a car to transport passengers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beans, wheat and quinoa.

loans.name: Juana Elsa

texts.es:
Juana  es socia del Bancomunal Avancemos Juntas, Juana tiene su negocio de ventas de carnes, nos cuenta que las ventas bajaron por la competencia de los supermercados que cada 15 días sacan ofertas de carne importada, y es mas barato, las personas prefieren comprar lo mas barato, ella vende carne nacional fresca. 
Juana necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles  para la compra de mercadería de carne y menudencia de vaca.
En Finca Perú ella ha logrado crecer en su negocio y crecer como persona, se siente mas segura su economía ha mejorado mucho.
El sueño de Juana es poder darle estudios superiores a su hija.

loans.use: carne y menudencia de vaca

loans.name: Olga Melania

texts.en:
Olga runs a business selling tortillas from her home. She makes her tortillas on her kitchen table and stovetop. She is requesting a loan to buy ingredients for her tortillas in bulk. If she can buy corn for her tortillas by the quintal (46kg or 101lbs), she will be able to sell her tortillas for less. This will make her more competitive.

Loans from CEPRODEL have helped Olga already. She said she likes that she can maintain herself and earn her own living. Olga is 41 years old. She is single with no children living at home. She has had a tortilla business for the last 4 years. Initially, she started her business with C$1,000 (US$ 50) that she received from her children.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making tortillas

loans.name: Jeg Diam Group

texts.fr:
La transformation traditionnelle des fruits et légumes est une pratique répandue dans notre écovillage (http://www.sem-fund.org/palmarin.php). Cependant, une proportion de fruits et légumes trop importante en est actuellement perdue après la récolte, faute de technologies de conservation. C’est pourquoi nous  venons auprès de kiva solliciter un prêt pour achat de matériel pour la transformation de fruits (mangue, ditakh) et légumes. C’est une activité que nous maitrisons vu que nous avons été bien formés. Après transformation  des fruits, nous allons les commercialiser sous la forme suivante : 
- stérilisés : fruits au sirop, confitures, compotes
- frais prêts à l'emploi à destination des consommateurs
texts.en:
The traditional processing of fruits and vegetables is a widespread practice in our eco village. (http://www.sem-fund.org/palmarin.php). However, a significant proportion of fruits and vegetables is currently wasted after harvest due to lack of conservation technologies. That is why we come to Kiva to request a loan for purchase of equipment for processing fruits(mangoes, ditakh) and vegetables. It is a business that we mastered in view of the fact that we have been well trained. After processing the fruits, we will sell them in the following way:- - sterilized: fruits in syrup, jam, compote - fresh and ready for the consumers

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for processing fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is 29 years old and married with a five-year-old daughter named Mercy. He has a kinyozi (barbershop) in Kitengela, a town near Nairobi. He has been in business for eight years and has two employees. He offers shaves and sells some small-scale goods in the shop.

He successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 KES from Faulu and requested this loan for 30,000 KES to promote the business and expand his shop.

loans.use: Add stock to retail business

loans.name: Arabua

texts.en:
Arabua M. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and bundles of firewood in the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  

Arabua is 39 years old and married to a car driver.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Nornalyn

texts.en:
Nornalyn C. is 39 years old. She has a small farm where she grows rice to be able to feed and clothe her family.  She started tilling the farm in 1993 and currently, her farm is doing well. She has a 17-year-old child who also helps her grow her crops.

Nornalyn said she likes the program of Community Economic Ventures Inc. because it offers an interest rate of only 2%. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 to buy farm supplies so as to grow healthy rice.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en: Fifty year old Celsa is still strong enough to perform farming duties. She is married and has four children. She cultivates her land for rice crops. She also joined CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines, to gain access to its financial services. She also wants her business to grow. She applied for a loan of PHP5,000, which will be used for purchasing farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: God Knows Group

texts.en:
Evelyn T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Knows. She is 40 years old and is married with four children between the ages of 6 to 20 years old and their educational levels are kindergarten to 12th grade. Evelyn could not continue her own education  through 12th grade due to poverty. She also cares for a niece. Evelyn and her family live and work at the Neezoe community Junction in Paynesville near Monrovia, Liberia. 

Evelyn’s business is the sales of general goods such as sardines, milk, etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells from a table at retail prices to residents of the Neezoe community in Paynesville. She has been running this business for six years and hopes to become an importer of clothing to Liberia in the near future.

Evelyn started selling with 5,000 LRD as her working capital, that was given to her by her husband. She sells daily needed goods and it attracts more customers to buy from her. Evelyn needs this loan to purchase more sardines, milk, etc. for resale to improve her business.
She dreams of all of her children being brought up in a good way to have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Evelyn is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more sardines, milk, etc. for resale to improve her business.

loans.name: Fishmonger B Akumu Joyce Group

texts.en: Joyce A. is this group's representative. She is a business lady of 29. She is married with four children, all going to school, and she takes care of one other dependent who is also in school. She sells fish and this has been her business for over five years. Due to insufficient capital, she is using the loan to add capital and purchase a big stock of fish for sale. She is a promising business lady whose dream is to improve on her family’s welfare.

loans.use: To add capital and purchase a stock of fish for sale

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:
Tina S. is 56 and married with 6 children (ages 12 - 31).  She owns a art business venture.  Tina has many years of experience in this business.  Tina needs a loan of WST $1700.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Tina joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Tina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Tina S. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase paints, graphic designs and varnish

loans.name: Marcial Juan

texts.es: El Sr. MARCIAL ESTA CASADO Y SE DEDICA A LA REPOSTERIA EN SU DOMICILIO, ACTUALMENTE ESTA ELABORANDO SALTEÑAS CON LA AYUDA DE LA ESPOSA QUIEN LAS VENDE EN PLENA ESQUINA DE LA CALLE 42, ACTIVIDAD CON LA QUE SOSTIENE A SU FAMILIA, QUE ESTA INTEGRADA POR LA PAREJA Y SUS 2 HIJOS PEQUEÑOS, LOS MISMOS QUE ESTAN ESTUDIANDO EN UNA ESCUELITA FISCAL DE LA ZONA , TAMBIEN PODEMOS INDICAR QUE EL CLIENTE ES MUY RESPONSABLE Y MUY CONOCIDO POR SUS VECINOS, SU DESEO ES DE TENER UNA PASTELERIA DONDE PUEDA OFRECER SUS PRODUCTOS Y TAMBIEN VER A SUS HIJOS PROFESIONALES, ESTA MUY AGRADECIDO CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Marcial is married and bakes from his home. Currently he makes salteñas (savory pastries) with the help of his wife, who sells them out on the corner of 42nd St. This activity supports their family, including the couple and their two young children, who study at the local public school. The client is very responsible and well known by his neighbors. He wants to open a bakery where he can sell his products as well as provide careers for his children. He is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence in him demonstrated by the loan offer.

Translated from Spanish by Amanda McDermott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase raw materials

loans.name: Afiafiese

texts.en:
Afiafiese S. is 41 and married with 8 children.  She owns a business venture, selling ice-cakes (flavored ice in styrofoam cups).  Afiafiese has 4 years of experience in this business.  Afiafiese needs a loan of WST $2450 to buy sugar, styrofoam cups, and codial (flavoring).  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Afiafi wishes to keep her business development on going as she requests for another fund to support and assist her family financially.  Afiafiese joined SPBD.  This is her 5th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Afiafiese's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy sugar, styrofoam cups, and codial (flavoring)

loans.name: Lomotos

texts.en:
Lomotos V. is from the village of Banigan, liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 40 years old. Lomotos is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Lomotos owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale. Lomotos has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lomotos joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Lomotos has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Lomotos is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used again to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lomotos from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Benjamin's Group

texts.en: Benjamin V. is from the village of Brgy. Manamtam, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 43 years old. Benjamin is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Benjamin is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Benjamin raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Benjamin has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Benjamin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benjamin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Benjamin is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan taken out by Benjamin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Essi Gameli

texts.fr:
Cette femme est âgée de 30 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Elle fait le commerce de pagnes depuis 06 ans. Elle associe à ce commerce celui de bijoux. Elle achète ses marchandises sur place à Lomé et les revend sur un étal au marché d’Assiyéyé. Présentement, elle est en rupture de stock. C’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite ce crédit de WAGES.
Comptant sur l’accroissement de son activité, elle espère mieux répondre aux besoins de scolarisation de ses 02 enfants
texts.en:
This woman is 30 years old, married, and the mother of two children.  She has been doing commerce in pagnes (colorful West African cloth) for six years.  She has included jewelry in her business.  She purchases her goods locally in Lomé, the capital of ToG., and resell them in her stall at the Assiyéyé market.  At present, she is out of stock.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan from WAGES.  Counting on growth in her business, she hopes to do better to meet the schooling needs of her two children. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pagne cloth and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Geovanny

texts.es: Geovanny U. H., tiene la edad de 31 años, está en unión libre, y vive con la compañera. El crédito lo quiere para hacer reparaciones en su casa. Desea comprar materiales para poder mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda. También terminar algunos trabajos inconclusos en su casa. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Geovanny se dedica a la agricultura, tiene varios años dedicado a la siembra del café. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
Geovanny U. H. is 31 years old and lives with his common-law wife. The loan he is requesting will go towards making repairs to his house. He hopes to buy materials to improve their living conditions. He would also like to complete some unfinished work on his house. This is the first time he is taking out a loan from FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the services they have offered him. Geovanny works in agriculture and has several years of experience cultivating coffee. In the future, he hopes to provide his family with a better quality of life and greater economic stability. He would also like to be able to continue growing as a person and as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita B. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 59 years old and married with ten adult children. To make a living, Teresita sells snacks in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC and is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used as down-payment on a motorcycle. This will be the third loan taken out by Teresita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: down-payment on a motorcycle

loans.name: Lev

texts.en: Lev M. is 38 years old and lives in a village in Kompong Cham Province. Since early 2008, she has made a living running a store in front of her home where she sells various items such as cooking ingredients, soft drinks, snacks, ice-cream and sweets for children. She typically makes $5 profit a day, which she uses to meet her family’s expenses. Her husband, Phan Oun, 44, is a farmer. This couple has three children, all of whom live at home and work in garment factories. With this loan, Lev M. will buy insecticide, fertilizer, a pump and seeds to use in planting a new crop. If any money is left over, she will use it to buy items to sell in her her store. The loan will help this family improve its standard of living.

loans.use: To buy insecticide, fertilizer, a pump and seeds.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 40 years old and married with three children.  Christine is a self-employed businesswoman known for selling a variety of goods in her small shop.  Christine opens her shop from 6 am until late in the evening hours.  

After four years in this business, her capital is still too low to earn more profit.  To end this, she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With the use of this loan, Christine will invest in foodstuffs such as rice, beans, peas, wheat etc.  As these foodstuffs are highly demanded, Christine hopes that she will attract more customers and, in addition, she will earn more profits.  With these earned profits, she will do her best to have better financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of foodstuffs

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es: Juan José tiene 54 años, su actividad es la compra y venta de chatarra Decidido a empezar una vida, Juan utilizo sus ahorros para empezar este negocio desde más de 7 años se dedica a este negocio, el tiene un excelente servicio, razón por la cual le dedica más empeño y dedicación todos los días Con este crédito que es el primero quiere comprar  llantas, repuestos para la camioneta y mas chatarra. El se siente muy contento pues quiere salir adelante para mejorar sus ingresos. Sueña con terminar de construir su vivienda y obtener otro carro.
texts.en:
Juan José, 54, buys and sells scrap. Determined to start a new life he started this business 7 years ago. He provides excellent service for which he must put in more work and dedication every day. This is his first loan and he plans to use the funds to buy tires, vehicle replacement parts and more scrap. He is happy because he wants to get ahead and improve his income. He dreams with finishing building his house and with getting another car.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tires, vehicle replacement parts and more recyclables.

loans.name: Guillermo

texts.es: Guillermo, de 62 años, es un hombre muy noble, vive en el comedor popular del estado, ya que se encarga del cuidado de inmueble, en compañía de su esposa y sus 2 hijos. Hace más de 10 años, se dedica en la venta de quesos y manjares que son provenientes de la sierra peruana, en donde sus familiares le proveen de estos productos lácteos para luego venderlos a vecinas y comerciantes minoristas del mercado de su distrito. La modalidad de sus ventas es a crédito; y cada semana renueva sus pedidos, de ese modo no pierde contacto con sus clientes. El resto de los días trabaja en múltiples labores de acuerdo a lo que se presente, mientras que termina de estudiar  su hija, ya que después piensa retornar a su pueblo donde tiene su propia casa. Es su veinteavo crédito con MFP y se compromete en continuar pagando puntualmente como hasta ahora, asimismo acudir a las reuniones que organiza el grupo. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en el incremento de quesos, manjares para abastecerse bien y cumplir con los pedidos pendientes que tiene.
texts.en:
Guillermo is 62 years old, he is a noble man. He is the caretaker of the State's buildings, and he lives there together with is wife and their two children. For more than 10 years he has sold cheeses and snacks that are popular in the Peruvian mountains. His family members provide him with the products for him to sell to the neighbors and the grocery stores in the market. He carries out his sales on credit and every week he receives orders for his products. This way he doesn't ever lose contact with his clients. The other days he works in various other jobs depending on whatever is required. Once her daughter is finished school he hopes to go back to the village where he has his own home. This is his twentieth loan through MFP (Kiva Field Partner) and he is committed to the obligations of the loan and he will continue to attend the group meetings. The loan he requests will be invested in the purchase of more cheeses and snacks to be able to supply the outstanding orders he currently has.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cheeses and snacks for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase supplies & fertilizers

loans.name: Nieve Margarita

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente dedicada  en gran parte a la agricultura y cría de  animales, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

Son muchos años los que la señora Nieves es socia del Banco Comunal y está muy cómoda ya que dice que las facilidades y beneficios que brinda la Fundación Espoir no lo va a encontrar en ninguna parte. Ella se encuentra casada hace muchos años y tuvo 6 hijos,  los mismos que ya tienen su propia familia solo su hija menor vive con ella y le acompaña. Su marido es agricultor.

Tiene un pequeño puesto de comida en el sector, trabaja todas las tardes ya que en la mañana se dedica a preparar todo lo que va a vender, además de comida prepara y vende ricos corviches y empanadas que a sus clientes les encantan, hay días que cierra su negocio a las 7 pm pero muchas veces a esa hora ya no tiene nada de lo que preparo, trabaja con la ayuda de su hija.

Espera comprar con este crédito unas mesas, sillas y productos para la preparación de sus deliciosos platos.

Su meta es tener un gran restaurante y gozar de mucha salud ella y los suyos.
texts.en:
In the parrish of Quiroga in the city of Calceta, an area where people are dedicated in large part to agriculture and raising animals, the Quiroga community bank meets every 15 days.

Nieves has been a member of the community bank for many years and she is very comfortable since the facilities and benefits provided to her by the Espoir Foundation cannot be found elsewhere. She has been married for many years and had six children, who now have their own families, except for her youngest daughter who lives with her and accompanies her. Her husband is a farmer.

She has a small food stand in the area. She works every evening since in the morning she is dedicated to preparing everything that she's going to sell. In addition to food, she prepares and sells delicious corviches and empanadas (fried food typical of the area) that her customers love. There are days when she closes her business at 7PM but many times, at that hour she no longer has anything to prepare. She works with the help of her daughter.

She hopes to buy with this loan some tables, chairs and products for the preparation of her delicious dishes.

Her goal is to have a great restaurant and that she and her family enjoy great health.

loans.use: Purchase tables, chairs and general groceries.

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
Dilorom K. is 53 years old. She is married with three children. With the purpose of helping her husband to support the family, Dilorom is running her own business. She sells jewelry and has been in this business for more than 7 years. Today, Dilorom is requesting $3,000 US Dollars. She is planning to purchase new items of jewelry like earrings, rings, bracelets, and chains in order to enlarge the range of goods for sale. This is the eighth loan for Dilorom and she promises to observe all the procedures concerning the payment of the loan as she did with her previous loans.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new items of jewelry for enlarging the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella A. is from Gala Ozamiz City. She is 54 years old. Estrella is widowed and has eight adult children. To make a living, Estrella owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting cassava and a variety of vegetables for sale. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Estrella joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the twelfth loan taken out by Estrella from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida I. is from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat,Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old. Loida is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Loida owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Loida has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Loida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Loida is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Loida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Dionita

texts.en:
68-year-old Dionita is a married woman from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has seven children. Most of her children have their own families already. Dionita has grandchildren already and she hopes to be able to extend help to them also.

Dionita earns a living by raising pigs for fattening. She sells pork meat to the market. She also helps her husband maintain their farm. She helps keep their rice crops healthy. 

Dionita needs feeds for the pigs and farm supplies for their rice farm. She is requesting a loan of Php 20, 000 that she will use to continue running her piggery and farm.

loans.use: To purchase feeds, seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: María Esther

texts.es:
La Señora María G. es socia del banco comunal Narancay Bajo, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es conocida como  Santa Ana de los cuatro ríos, su centro histórico en diciembre de 1999 fue nombrado patrimonio cultural de la humanidad.
 
Nuestra socia tiene 38 años, es madre soltera de 2 hijas de 15 y 6 años de edad, la primera hija  estudia en el colegio y su segunda en una escuela de la ciudad, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive en casa de su papá  donde comparten los gastos.
 
Doña María es comerciante y se dedica a la venta de hortalizas, frutas, quesillos, etc., actividad que la desempeña hace 20 años, tiene un puesto propio en el mercado de la feria libre, labora de lunes a viernes desde las 9 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde.
 
Este es su primer crédito y fue invitada por su prima a ser socia del  banco comunal,  el dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de hortalizas y más frutas. Su meta es darles  a sus hijas una buena educación.
texts.en:
Maria G. is a member of the community bank Narancay Bajo. She lives in the city of Cuenca. This city is known as Santa Ana of the four rivers. In December of 1999, its historic center was named a cultural heritage of humanity. 

This member is 38 years old. She is a single mother of two daughters of ages 15 and 6. Her first daughter is in school and her second is in a city school. She does not have her own home which is why she lives at her father's house and they share their expenses. 

Maria is a merchant. She sells vegetables, fruits and cheeses which she has been doing for 20 years. She has her own stall in the free fair market. She works from Monday to Friday, from 9:00 A.M. until 6:00 P.M. 

This is her first loan with the bank. Her cousin invited her to be a member of the community bank. She will use the money from her loan to invest in purchasing vegetables and more fruit. Her goals is to provide her daughters with a good education.

loans.use: Buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Safina

texts.en: Safina sells vegetables for a living. She is 35 years old and is a widow with five children. Safina has been selling vegetables for fifteen years. Her loan will be used to purchase more vegetables, such as tomatoes, to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business for her family's expenses and to pay school fees for her children. She dreams of having either a big shop or a motorcycle in the future.

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Herlinda Janneth

texts.es:
Herlinda de 52 años, vive en una zona periurbana llamada Fortín. Esta divorciada pero tiene tres hijos. Ella no tuvo oportunidades laborables por eso opto por ser comerciante informal de sabanas.

Su trabajo lo realiza sola ya que comienza a trabajar desde las 09h00am hasta que termina el trabajo vendiendo las sabanas desde $ 30.00 en adelante. Uno de los inconvenientes que ahora tiene es la temporada de lluvia y se le dificulta caminar con las sabanas. 

Continuar con su negocio es una de sus aspiraciones por eso quiere comprar con el préstamo sabanas, almohadones para seguir vendiendo a sus conocidos y vecinos. En el futuro quiere incrementar su mercadería.
texts.en:
Herlinda is 52 years old and lives in a peri-urban area called Fortín.  She is divorced but has three children.

Herlinda didn't have any work opportunities and so, for this reason, she chose to sell sheets as an informal saleswoman.  She works alone and works from 9.00am until she finishes her work, selling her sheets for $30 and upwards.

One of the disadvantages Herlinda currently has is that it is the rainy season.  This makes it difficult for her to walk with her sheets.  She wishes to continue with her business and so would like to use her loan to buy sheets and pillows so that she can continue selling to her acquaintances and neighbors.  In the future, she would like to increase her merchandise.

loans.use: To buy sheets and pillows

loans.name: Isrrael Group

texts.es: El banco D. emprendimiento "Israel" es un banco nuevo  se encuentra en su primer ciclo son clientes que ya tienen experiencia en otras instituciones son D. la zona D. villa Israel todos  viven en la misma zona y la institución esta entrando con apertura D. bancos nuevos ellas sacaron el crédito para aumentar su capital D. trabajo, la representante del grupo es la Sr. María se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes, tiene una tienda donD. venD. solo abarrotes , ella esta separada D. su esposo tiene 2  hijos dedica  a esta actividad ya hace muchos años, es una persona muy trabajadora y con el dinero del crédito comprara mercadería por mayor D. arroz, azúcar, aceite , etc. Todas las socias esta muy agradecidas con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: The communal bank "Israel" is a new bank and it is in its first cycle. Its customers have had experience with other institutions. They are from the Villa Israel area and they all live in the same area. This institution is opening new banks. They have obtained this loan to increase their working capital. The representative of the group is Maria. She has a store where she only sells groceries. She has been in this business for many years. She is separated from her husband and has two children. She is a hardworking person and with the money from this loan she will buy merchandise wholesale such as rice, sugar, oil, etc. All of the members are very thankful to this institution for the support it has provided them.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of groceries.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn V. is from the town of Tagbilaran. She is 41 years old. Marilyn is married and has 3 children aged 21, 20 and 13. To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector operating a furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Marilyn works hard to sustain her children's education.

Marilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Juan Marcos

texts.es: Don Juan se dedica a la elaboración de cereales desde hace seis años, anteriormente trabajo en una fabrica donde elaboraban dichos productos, aprendio el proceso de elaboración y se independizo y comenzó con negocio propio desde hace tres años realizando sus ventas en ferias locales, actualmente vive en la localidad de el paso, vive con su esposa y sus tres hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar. Solicita el crédito para comprar insumos al por mayor ya que los precios van subiendo rápidamente y prefiere tener almacenado para evitar el alza de precios de sus insumos para la elaboración de cereales, es una persona joven trabajadora que esta agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.  OJO en la foto aparece junto a la promotora de ventas.
texts.en:
Don Juan has earned his living making cereals for 6 years.  Earlier he worked in a cereal factory and learned the process.  Three years ago, he went out on his own and started his own business, selling his product at local fairs.  Now his lives in Paso with his wife and their three school-aged children.  

Don Juan is seeking a loan to buy ingredients wholesale.  Prices are going up up rapidly and he would rather store the goods to avoid the price hikes.  He is a young, hard-working person and is very grateful to the Institutión for its support. He appears in the photo along with his sales promoter.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make cereals.

loans.name: Juan Manuel

texts.es:
Juan tiene 38 años de edad, es casado y tiene dos hijos. Vive en casa propia la cual está ubicada en la parte rural del distrito de Túcume en la región de Lambayeque. 

Desde hace tres años, Juan se dedica a la animación de fiestas sociales para la cual posee equipo de sonido propio. Actualmente, dirige el negocio de su domicilio. No hay mejor competencia en la zona porque conoce a la perfección el rubro y cuenta con una clientela ya establecida en la zona.
